dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so I'm reading this article, right? And it says here, the Fed, ECB, Bank of Japan, Bank of England â€“ all of them are injecting a staggering $22 trillion into financial systems. Twenty-two trillion!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I'm reading this article, right? And it says here, the Fed, E C B, Bank of Japan, Bank of England - all of them are injecting a staggering twenty two dollars trillion into financial systems. Twenty-two trillion!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my god, like, that's literally the annual U.S. output, right? I saw that too!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my god, like, that's literally the annual U.S. output, right? I saw that too!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The roughly $22 trillion of liquidity the Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, Bank of Japan and Bank of England are pumping into financial systems matches the size of annual U.S. output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! It's just... it's just mind-boggling. And it's a "desperate measure" they're calling it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! It's just... it's just mind-boggling. And it's a desperate measure they're calling it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Desperate, yeah! Because, uh, with all these new viral outbreaks and everything, demand is just crushed. From China to Brazil, it's like...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Desperate, yeah! Because, uh, with all these new viral outbreaks and everything, demand is just crushed. From China to Brazil, it's like...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That may be just the start, as the odds of new outbreaks threaten to pulverize demand from China to Brazil.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Total global slowdown. And the article says this could mean a decade of stagnation. A whole decade!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Total global slowdown. And the article says this could mean a decade of stagnation. A whole decade!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its also a reason to worry about a lost decade for global growth that sets back living standards more than economists and investors realize.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, like, way worse than investors even foresee, you know? And it brings up Japan. Always Japan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, like, way worse than investors even foresee, you know? And it brings up Japan. Always Japan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its also a reason to worry about a lost decade for global growth that sets back living standards more than economists and investors realize.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Japan has been in, um, deflation for decades. And they pioneered quantitative easing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Japan has been in, um, deflation for decades. And they pioneered quantitative easing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As if often the case in gloomy economic moments, attention turns to Japan, where deflation has been the reality for two decades now. ... Since 1999, zero interest rates have been the norm in Japan, which pioneered quantitative easing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for like, twenty years! Zero interest rates since '99. And it still hasn't, like, really worked for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for like, twenty years! Zero interest rates since 'ninety nine. And it still hasn't, like, really worked for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though the BOJ made some progress since 2013 generating upward price pressures, the deflationary mindset Governor Haruhiko Kuroda sought to change is reasserting itself. ... Since 1999, zero interest rates have been the norm in Japan

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No! It just, um, actually ended up enriching the asset-owning elite, didn't it? That whole idea of "wealth transfer."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! It just, um, actually ended up enriching the asset-owning elite, didn't it? That whole idea of wealth transfer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The longer it persisted, the more ultra-easy policies morphed into a regressive wealth transfer to the haves from the have-nots. ... The same is true of Japan, an economy once prized for egalitarianism. Though rising competition from China is depressing wages, QE policies enriched the land- and asset-owning class at the expense of the masses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! It's that painful truth: audacious monetary easing, uh, sows the seeds of longer-term economic woes. Like the 2008 crisis, Bernanke.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! It's that painful truth: audacious monetary easing, uh, sows the seeds of longer-term economic woes. Like the two thousand eight crisis, Bernanke.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet, as Japan shows, audacious monetary easing tends to make things worst in the longer run. ... The Fed shouldve learned this lesson after 2008. At the time, then-Chairman Ben Bernanke embraced QE to save an economy essentially hurtling off a cliff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it created these "zombie firms" in Japan, too. Companies that should have, like, failed, but stayed afloat on cheap money.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it created these zombie firms in Japan, too. Companies that should have, like, failed, but stayed afloat on cheap money.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over time, though, its led to the zombie-fication of so much of Japans entire economy. ... Companies came to depend on loans to stay afloat, while dwindling profits make it hard to cover debt payments. As industries become bogged down with corporate zombies, they become less vibrant.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! No pressure to innovate, no reason for CEOs to strengthen strategy. They just... existed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! No pressure to innovate, no reason for CEOs to strengthen strategy. They just... existed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that free money took the onus off CEOs to raise their competitive games. Companies came to depend on loans to stay afloat

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the big worry is, the US, Eurozone, the UK are basically doing the exact same thing. Following that playbook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the big worry is, the U S, Eurozone, the U K are basically doing the exact same thing. Following that playbook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S., eurozone and U.K. are on a similar trajectory as the central banks play the role of mere ATMs... ...officials in Washington, Frankfurt, London and elsewhere read from the same playbook.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Like, they're becoming these, uh, ATMs, for the G4 monetary authorities. A $22 trillion ATM.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Like, they're becoming these, uh, ATMs, for the G4 monetary authorities. A twenty two dollars trillion A T M.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S., eurozone and U.K. are on a similar trajectory as the central banks play the role of mere ATMsa $22 trillion ATM among just the G4 monetary authorities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But it won't boost productivity, right? It won't narrow the rich-poor gap.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it won't boost productivity, right? It won't narrow the rich-poor gap.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All that largess wont increase Americas productivity or narrow the rich-poor divide.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! It just, um, accelerates the upward flow of wealth, basically. Free money comes with a very high price.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! It just, um, accelerates the upward flow of wealth, basically. Free money comes with a very high price.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But with no vibrant export destination and few true reformers in government, all that cash is likely to accelerate the trickling up of wealth away from middle- and lower-income households. Free money is coming at a huge cost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A very high price. It's just so frustrating to see, like, the same mistakes, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A very high price. It's just so frustrating to see, like, the same mistakes, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! It's like a repeating cycle, only... bigger.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! It's like a repeating cycle, only... bigger.
